title: Damage cell quality control
text: goal DamageDetective simplify process making informed reproducible damaged cell filtering decisions single cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) data pre-processing. tutorial provides outline steps needed achieve DamageDetective, Data preparation Parameter selection Damaged cell detection Ensure following packages installed made available R environment follow along tutorial. DamageDetective, SeuratData, Seurat, scRNAseq , SingleCellExperiment.

title: Damage cell quality control
text: entirety tutorial take place R, home three popular scRNA-seq data storage types, Seurat object SingleCellExperiment (sce) class directly matrix compiled alignment output, matrix.mtx, barcodes.tsv, features.tsv. DamageDetective operates data compressed, column-oriented sparse matrix (dgCMatrix). format efficiently handles sparse nature single-cell data indexing nonzero elements within column. damage simulation core DamageDetective involves multiple column-wise operations, preferred input format. data types can act starting point damage detection conversion sparse matrix.

title: Damage cell quality control
text: use SeuratData package retrieve publicly available Seurat object demonstration. object stores data peripheral blood mononuclear cells, PBMCs, sequenced using 10X Genomics platform. Upon loading, see Seurat object contains 2700 cells 13 714 features. count matrix can extracted assay slot object , default, already compressed column-oriented sparse form. counts can now used input DamageDetective.
code: # Retrieve the dataset of interest SeuratData::InstallData("pbmc3k") data("pbmc3k") # View dimensions & class # class(pbmc3k)[1] # dim(pbmc3k) #  # # Extract the count matrix # pbmc3k_counts <- pbmc3k[["RNA"]]$counts #  # # View data # class(pbmc3k_counts)[1] # dim(pbmc3k_counts)

title: Damage cell quality control
text: use publicly available alignment data 10X Genomics website demonstration, specifically ‘1k PBMCs healthy donor (v3)’ data available following link named “Feature / cell matrix (filtered)”. alignment output comes form three files containing row names (genes), column names (cell identifiers), input values (counts) count matrix. can compiled using Seurat’s ReadMtx simplifies count matrix compilation one function. involves uncompressing zipped files, mapping feature names HGNC gene symbols, converting matrix sparse format. ReadMtx output can used directly DamageDetective. Upon converting, see dataset contains 1222 cells 33 538 genes.
code: # Set the file paths relative to location on your device matrix_file <- "~/Projects/demonstrations/matrix.mtx.gz"      barcodes_file <- "~/Projects/demonstrations/barcodes.tsv.gz"  features_file <- "~/Projects/demonstrations/features.tsv.gz"   # Construct the sparse matrix alignment_counts <- Seurat::ReadMtx(   mtx = matrix_file,   cells = barcodes_file,   features = features_file ) unlink(extracted_dir, recursive = TRUE, force = TRUE) # View output class(alignment_counts)[1] #> [1] "dgCMatrix" dim(alignment_counts) #> [1] 33538  1222

title: Damage cell quality control
text: use scRNAseq package retrieve publicly available sce object demonstration. object stores PBMC data multiple samples study investigating influenza yellow fever vaccine responsiveness. focus “234_d0” sample coming individual high vaccine responsiveness. Upon loading, see object contains 2358 cells 32 738 features. count matrix stored delayed matrix within assay slot sce object. format enables memory-efficient operations delaying computations explicitly requested, rather storing values memory upfront. However, DamageDetective computations require repeated access matrix delays request greatly accumulate slow process. Thus, must convert delayed matrix required DamageDetective format sparse matrix using dense matrix intermediate.
code: # Retrieve multisample dataset pbmc_sce <- scRNAseq::fetchDataset("kotliarov-pbmc-2020", "2024-04-18")  # Extract barcodes of the sample of interest metadata <- SummarizedExperiment::colData(pbmc_sce) sample_sce <- subset(metadata, sample == "234_d0") sample_sce <- rownames(sample_sce)  # Isolate counts from multisample and subset for sample of interest pbmc_counts <- SummarizedExperiment::assay(pbmc_sce, "counts") sample_counts  <- pbmc_counts[, sample_sce]  # Convert delayed to sparse format sample_counts <- as.matrix(sample_counts) sample_counts <- as(sample_counts, "dgCMatrix")  # View output class(sample_counts)[1] #> [1] "dgCMatrix" dim(sample_counts) #> [1] 32738  2358

title: Damage cell quality control
text: Damage detection carried detect_damage function requires one input run, count matrix, accepts additional parameters. can divided two categories, adjust computation result different output, computation parameters, adjust user receives output computation change , aesthetic parameters. explored briefly deciding appropriate selections.

title: Damage cell quality control
text: Dataset-defined parameters, choice input predetermined input data cases needs alteration default case. includes specifying organism data came (human default) whether data contains annotated_celltypes (default FALSE). ribosome_penalty parameter determined input data requires computational work uncover, work must done input dataset. parameter accounts unexpectedly lower probability ribosomal RNA loss observed real single cell data expected based transcript abundance alone. images loss cytoplasmic RNA  Table summarising detect_damage parameters

title: Damage cell quality control
code: organism = "Hsap", annotated_celltypes = FALSE, target_damage = c(0.1, 0.8), damage_distribution = "right_skewed", distribution_steepness = "moderate", beta_shape_parameters = NULL,

title: Damage cell quality control

title: Detecting Damaged Cells in Single-Cell RNA Sequencing Data
text: View DamageDetective website Damaged cells class low-quality artifact targeted quality control (QC) single-cell RNA-seq (scRNA-seq) data. cells succumbed stress sequenced result contain gene expression data fails describe cells true, viable states. Current approaches detect damage according deviation cell-level QC metrics. approaches assume viable cells follow similar distributions across QC metrics, assumption hold heterogeneous samples. recent methods address analysing cells population level, isolating cells similar distributions assessing deviations within amoung . Howevere, assumes distinct distributions associated viable cell populations meaning damaged cells abundant enough form distinct population, risk misclassification. Ultimately, filtering decisions current approaches controlled statistical definitions deviation biological definitions damage. DamageDetective takes different approach inspired DoubletFinder1^1, high performing tool doublet QC, another low quality scRNA-seq artifact. , rather detecting damage measuring extent cells deviate , damage detected measuring extent cells deviate artificially damaged profiles . DamageDetective estimates damage severity true cells score 0 1, providing intuitive, reproducible scale filtering standardised across cell types, samples, experiments.

previous_headings: Quick start > Select parameters for damage detection
title: Detecting Damaged Cells in Single-Cell RNA Sequencing Data
text: DamageDetective provide binary classifications, “cell” “damage”, provides score 0 1 indicating estimated extent damage cell. taken directly extent cytoplasmic RNA loss, proportion ranging 0 1, set artificial cells true cell greatest proximity . words, user must choose value 0 1 determine level damage, proportion RNA loss, cells excluded. default, DamageDetective offers threshold 0.7. Values greater 0.7 reflect permissive filtering closer 0 reflect stringent filtering. recommend default cases suggest adjustments made, informed inspecting output detect_damage plots, generate_plot = TRUE. remaining parameters detect_damage can explored function help page introduction article online.

title: Detecting Damaged Cells in Single-Cell RNA Sequencing Data
text: Damage detection can run using count matrix selected parameters inputs. specified filter_counts parameter TRUE. use default filter_threshold identify cells removal return filtered count matrix output. Note, assumes data human origin, see organism parameter.  Alternatively, filter_counts set FALSE, data frame given output containing damage scores barcode. provided interest user wish interact DamageDetective results directly. , user can filter data done filter_counts.
code: # Perform damage detection detection_results <- detect_damage(   count_matrix = test_counts,   ribosome_penalty = penalty,   filter_counts = TRUE,   seed = 7 ) # Simulating cells between 1e-05 and 0.08 RNA loss... # Simulating cells between 0.1 and 0.3 RNA loss... # Simulating cells between 0.3 and 0.5 RNA loss... # Simulating cells between 0.5 and 0.7 RNA loss... # Simulating cells between 0.7 and 0.9 RNA loss... # Computing pANN...  # View the resulting count matrix dim(detection_results$output) # [1] 32738   470 # Perform damage detection detection_results <- detect_damage(   count_matrix = test_counts,   ribosome_penalty = penalty,   filter_counts = FALSE,   seed = 7 ) # Simulating cells between 1e-05 and 0.08 RNA loss... # Simulating cells between 0.1 and 0.3 RNA loss... # Simulating cells between 0.3 and 0.5 RNA loss... # Simulating cells between 0.5 and 0.7 RNA loss... # Simulating cells between 0.7 and 0.9 RNA loss... # Computing pANN...  # View output print(head(detection_results$output), row.names = FALSE) #                     Cells DamageDetective # TCTGGAAAGCCCAACC_H1B2ln6      0.03826609 # CCGTTCATCGTGGGAA_H1B2ln2      0.48333333 # CTTCTCTTCAGCCTAA_H1B2ln1      0.05217739 # GGATTACAGGGATGGG_H1B2ln1      0.01044348 # TCTATTGTCTGGTATG_H1B2ln2      0.02435478 # ACGGGTCAGACAAGCC_H1B2ln6      0.28888889  # Filter matrix  undamaged_cells <- filter(detection_results$output, DamageDetective < 0.7) filtered_matrix <- test_counts[, undamaged_cells] dim(filtered_matrix) # [1] 32738   470

title: detect_damage — detect_damage
text: Quality control function identify filter damaged cells input count matrix, 'damage' defined loss cytoplasmic RNA.

title: detect_damage — detect_damage
code: detect_damage(   count_matrix,   ribosome_penalty = 0.01,   organism = "Hsap",   annotated_celltypes = FALSE,   target_damage = c(0.1, 0.8),   damage_distribution = "right_skewed",   distribution_steepness = "moderate",   beta_shape_parameters = NULL,   damage_levels = 5,   damage_proportion = 0.15,   seed = 7,   mito_quantile = 0.75,   kN = NULL,   generate_plot = TRUE,   display_plot = TRUE,   palette = c("grey", "#7023FD", "#E60006"),   filter_threshold = 0.7,   filter_counts = FALSE,   verbose = TRUE )

title: detect_damage — detect_damage
text: count_matrix Matrix dgCMatrix containing counts single cell RNA sequencing data. ribosome_penalty Numeric specifying factor probability loosing transcript ribosomal gene multiplied . , values closer 0 represent greater penalty. Default 0.01. organism String specifying organism origin input data two standard options, "Hsap" "Mmus" user wishes use non-standard organism must input list containing strings patterns match mitochondrial ribosomal genes organism. available, nuclear-encoded genes likely retained nucleus, nuclear speckles, must also specified. example humans , organism = c(mito_pattern = "^MT-", ribo_pattern = "^(RPS|RPL)", nuclear <- c("NEAT1","XIST", "MALAT1") Default "Hsap" annotated_celltypes Boolean specifying whether input matrix cell type information stored. Default FALSE target_damage Numeric vector specifying upper lower range level damage introduced. , damage refers amount cytoplasmic RNA lost cell values closer 1 indicate loss therefore heavily damaged cells. Default c(0.1, 0.8) damage_distribution String specifying whether distribution damage levels among damaged cells shifted towards upper lower range damage specified 'target_damage' follow symmetric distribution . three valid options: "right_skewed" "left_skewed" "symmetric" Default "right_skewed" distribution_steepness String specifying concentrated spread damaged cells mean target distribution specified 'target_damage'. , increase steepness manifests apparent skewness.three valid options: "shallow" "moderate" "steep" Default "moderate" beta_shape_parameters Numeric vector allows shape parameters beta distribution defined explicitly. offers greater flexibility allowed 'damage_distribution' 'distribution_steepness' parameters override defaults offer. Default 'NULL' damage_levels Numeric specifying number distinct sets artificial damaged cells simulated, defined range loss. Default ptions include, 3 : c(0.00001, 0.08), c(0.1, 0.4), c(0.5, 0.9) 5 : c(0.00001, 0.08), c(0.1, 0.3), c(0.3, 0.5), c(0.5, 0.7), c(0.7, 0.9) 7 : c(0.00001, 0.08), c(0.1, 0.3), c(0.3, 0.4), c(0.4, 0.5), c(0.5, 0.7), c(0.7, 0.9), c(0.9, 0.99999). user can also provide list specifying sets ranges loss, damage_levels = list( pANN_50 = c(0.1, 0.5), pANN_100 = c(0.5, 1) ) introducing sets damage user can improve accuracy loss estimations (scaled_pANN) found scaling pANN within set according lower upper boundary set's damage level. However, introducing sets increases computational time function. Default 5. damage_proportion Numeric describing proportion input data altered resemble damaged data. Must range 0 1. seed Numeric specifying random seed ensure reproducibility function's output. Setting seed ensures random sampling perturbation processes produce results function run multiple times input data parameters. Default 7. mito_quantile Numeric 0 1 specifying level mitochondrial proportion cells sampled simulations. step done protect simulating damaged cell profiles cells likely damaged. Default 0.75. kN Numeric describing many nearest neighbours considered pANN calculations. kN exceed total cell number. Default one third total cell number. generate_plot Boolean specifying whether QC plot outputted. QC plots generated default recommend verifying perturbed data retains characteristics true single cell data. Default TRUE. display_plot Boolean specifying whether output QC plot displayed global environment. Naturally, relevant generate_plot TRUE. Default TRUE. palette String specifying three colours used create continuous colour palette colouring 'damage_column'. Default range purple red, c("grey", "#7023FD", "#E60006"). filter_threshold Numeric specifying proportion RNA loss cell considered damaged. Default 0.75. filter_counts Boolean specifying whether output matrix filtered, returned containing cells fall filter threshold. Alternatively, data frame containing cell barcodes associated label either 'damaged' 'cell' returned. Default FALSE. verbose Boolean specifying whether messages function progress displayed console. Default TRUE.

title: detect_damage — detect_damage
text: Filtered matrix data frame containing damage labels.

title: detect_damage — detect_damage
text: Using simulation framework simulate_counts(), detect_damage() generates artificially damaged cell profiles introducing defined levels RNA loss input data. True artificial cells merged pre-processed compute following quality control metrics: Log-normalized feature count Log-normalized total counts Mitochondrial proportion Ribosomal proportion Log-normalized MALAT1 gene expression Principal component analysis (PCA) performed metrics, Euclidean distance matrix constructed PC embeddings. true cell, proportion nearest neighbours artificial cells (pANN) calculated across damage levels damage level highest pANN assigned true cell. Finally, cells exceeding specified damage threshold, filter_threshold, marked damaged. filtering method inspired approaches developed DoubletFinder (McGinnis et al., 2019) detect doublets single-cell data.

title: detect_damage — detect_damage
text: McGinnis, C. S., Murrow, L. M., & Gartner, Z. J. (2019). DoubletFinder: Doublet Detection Single-Cell RNA Sequencing Data Using Artificial Nearest neighbours. Cell Systems, 8(4), 329-337.e4. doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.03.003

title: select_penalty — select_penalty
text: Recommended prerequisite function detect_damage() estimates ideal ribosome_penalty value input data.

title: select_penalty — select_penalty
code: select_penalty(   count_matrix,   organism = "Hsap",   mito_quantile = 0.75,   penalty_range = c(1e-05, 0.5),   penalty_step = 0.005,   max_penalty_trials = 10,   target_damage = c(0.2, 0.99),   damage_distribution = "right_skewed",   distribution_steepness = "steep",   beta_shape_parameters = NULL,   stability_limit = 3,   damage_proportion = 0.15,   annotated_celltypes = FALSE,   return_output = "penalty",   ribosome_penalty = NULL,   seed = NULL,   verbose = TRUE )

title: select_penalty — select_penalty
text: count_matrix Matrix dgCMatrix containing counts single cell RNA sequencing data. organism String specifying organism origin input data two standard options, "Hsap" "Mmus" user wishes use non-standard organism must input list containing strings patterns match mitochondrial ribosomal genes organism. available, nuclear-encoded genes likely retained nucleus, nuclear speckles, must also specified. example humans , organism = c(mito_pattern = "^MT-", ribo_pattern = "^(RPS|RPL)", nuclear <- c("NEAT1","XIST", "MALAT1") Default "Hsap" mito_quantile Numeric specifying proportion mitochondrial content cells used sampling simulation. Default 0.75, meaning cells less 0.75 proportion mitochondrial counts sampled simulated. penalty_range Numerical vector length 2 specifying lower upper limit values tested ribosomal penalty. Default c(0.00001, 0.5). penalty_step Numeric specifying value added increment penalty tested. Default 0.005. max_penalty_trials Numeric specifying maximum number iterations ribosomal penalty value. Default 10. target_damage Numeric vector specifying upper lower range level damage introduced. , damage refers amount cytoplasmic RNA lost cell values closer 1 indicate loss therefore heavily damaged cells. Default c(0.1, 0.8) damage_distribution String specifying whether distribution damage levels among damaged cells shifted towards upper lower range damage specified 'target_damage' follow symmetric distribution . three valid options: "right_skewed" "left_skewed" "symmetric" Default "right_skewed" distribution_steepness String specifying concentrated spread damaged cells mean target distribution specified 'target_damage'. , increase steepness manifests apparent skewness.three valid options: "shallow" "moderate" "steep" Default "moderate" beta_shape_parameters Numeric vector allows shape parameters beta distribution defined explicitly. offers greater flexibility allowed 'damage_distribution' 'distribution_steepness' parameters override defaults offer. Default 'NULL' stability_limit Numeric specifying number additional iterations allotted median minimum distance artificial cells true cells greater previous minimum distance. idea higher penalty causing improvement output, little need continue testing larger penalties. Default 3. damage_proportion Numeric describing proportion input data altered resemble damaged data. Must range 0 1. annotated_celltypes Boolean specifying whether input matrix cell type information stored. Default FALSE return_output String specifying form output function take options either, "penalty" "full" "Penalty" return ribosomal penalty resulted best performance (smallest median distance artificial true cells). "full" return ideal ribosomal penalty median distance artificial true cells penalty tested. allows insight penalty selected. Default "penalty". ribosome_penalty Numeric specifying factor probability loosing transcript ribosomal gene multiplied . , values closer 0 represent greater penalty. Default 0.01. seed Numeric specifying random seed ensure reproducibility function's output. Setting seed ensures random sampling perturbation processes produce results function run multiple times input data parameters. Default 7. verbose Boolean specifying whether messages function progress displayed console. Default TRUE.

title: select_penalty — select_penalty
text: Numeric representing ideal ribosomal penalty input dataset.

title: select_penalty — select_penalty
text: Based observations true single cell data, find ribosomal RNA loss occurs less frequently expected based abundance alone. adjust , probability scores ribosomal gene loss multiplied numerical value (ribosome_penalty) 0 1. Lower values (closer zero) better approximate true data, default 0.01, though can often greatly refined input data. Refinement follows similar workflow detect_damage, rather evaluating similarity true cells sets artificial cells infer level damage, evaluate similarity artificial cells true cells infer effectiveness approximation true data. calculated using distance nearest true cell (dTNN) taken artificial cell found using Euclidean distance matrix. median dTNN computed iteratively stabilization worsening trend. ideal ribosomal_penalty selected generated lowest dTNN.

title: select_penalty — select_penalty
code: data("test_counts", package = "DamageDetective")  penalty <- select_penalty(  count_matrix = test_counts,  stability_limit = 1,  max_penalty_trials = 1,  seed = 7 ) #> Testing penalty of 1e-05... #> Maximum penalty trials reached (1). Stopping.

Must range 0 1. annotated_celltypes Boolean specifying whether input matrix cell type information stored. Default FALSE target_damage Numeric vector specifying upper lower range level damage introduced. , damage refers amount cytoplasmic RNA lost cell values closer 1 indicate loss therefore heavily damaged cells. Default c(0.1, 0.8) damage_distribution String specifying whether distribution damage levels among damaged cells shifted towards upper lower range damage specified 'target_damage' follow symmetric distribution . three valid options: "right_skewed" "left_skewed" "symmetric" Default "right_skewed" distribution_steepness String specifying concentrated spread damaged cells mean target distribution specified 'target_damage'. , increase steepness manifests apparent skewness.three valid options: "shallow" "moderate" "steep" Default "moderate" beta_shape_parameters Numeric vector allows shape parameters beta distribution defined explicitly. offers greater flexibility allowed 'damage_distribution' 'distribution_steepness' parameters override defaults offer. Default 'NULL' ribosome_penalty Numeric specifying factor probability loosing transcript ribosomal gene multiplied . , values closer 0 represent greater penalty. Default 0.01. generate_plot Boolean specifying whether QC plot outputted. QC plots generated default recommend verifying perturbed data retains characteristics true single cell data. Default TRUE. display_plot Boolean specifying whether output QC plot displayed global environment. Naturally, relevant generate_plot TRUE. Default TRUE. seed Numeric specifying random seed ensure reproducibility function's output. Setting seed ensures random sampling perturbation processes produce results function run multiple times input data parameters. Default 7. organism String specifying organism origin input data two standard options, "Hsap" "Mmus" user wishes use non-standard organism must input list containing strings patterns match mitochondrial ribosomal genes organism. available, nuclear-encoded genes likely retained nucleus, nuclear speckles, must also specified. example humans , organism = c(mito_pattern = "^MT-", ribo_pattern = "^(RPS|RPL)", nuclear <- c("NEAT1","XIST", "MALAT1") Default "Hsap"

title: simulate_counts — simulate_counts
text: list containing altered count matrix, data frame summary statistics, , specified, 'ggplot2' object quality control metrics alteration.

title: simulate_counts — simulate_counts
text: DamageDetective models damage single-cell RNA sequencing data loss cytoplasmic RNA, cells experiencing greater RNA loss assumed extensively damaged, minimal loss considered largely intact. perturbation process introduces RNA loss existing cells controlled three key parameters: target proportion damage,  specifies fraction cells perturbed; target level damage, defines extent RNA loss across cells; target distribution damage, determines different levels RNA loss distributed across cells. Based parameters, cells randomly selected assigned target proportion RNA loss. total number transcripts removed determined, perturbation applied weighted sampling without replacement cytoplasmic gene counts. , probability transcript loss determined gene abundance, highly expressed genes likely lose transcripts. target RNA loss reached, cell's expression profile updated, process repeats selected cells.

title: simulate_counts — simulate_counts
code: data("test_counts", package = "DamageDetective")  simulated_damage <- simulate_counts(   count_matrix = test_counts,   damage_proportion = 0.1,   ribosome_penalty = 0.01,   target_damage = c(0.5, 0.9),   generate_plot = FALSE,   seed = 7 )

title: DamageDetective 0.0.1
